profileText: A Representative from Illinois; born in Paris, Bourbon County, Ky., February 22, 1794; pursued classical studies; during the War of 1812 was commissioned ensign in the Seventeenth Infantry; promoted to first lieutenant in the Forty-sixth Infantry July 16, 1814, and returned to the Seventeenth Infantry July 16, 1814; received, by resolution of Congress, February 13, 1835, the testimonial of a sword for his part in the defense of Fort Stephenson, Ohio; moved to Illinois in 1818 and settled in Kaskaskia, later in Jackson County; engaged in agricultural pursuits; justice of the peace in Jackson County 1821-1823; appointed major general of State militia in 1822 and commanded Illinois troops in the Black Hawk War in 1831; member of the State senate 1824-1826; elected as a Jacksonian to the Twentieth and to the three succeeding Congresses and served from March 4, 1827, until September 21, 1834, when he resigned, having been elected Governor of Illinois; moved to Jacksonville, Ill., in 1829; Governor of Illinois 1834-1838; unsuccessful candidate for Governor in 1842; lived in retirement until his death in Jacksonville, Morgan County, Ill., January 15, 1844; interment in Diamond Grove Cemetery.

note.content: Resigned September 21, 1834, having been elected governor of Illinois.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Kirby, Julia [Smith] (Duncan). Biographical sketch of Joseph Duncan, Fifth Governor of Illinois. Chicago: Fergus Printing Company, 1888.
Putnam, Elizabeth Duncan. The Life and Services of Joseph Duncan: Governor of Illinois, 1834-1838. Springfield, Ill.: Illinois State Journal Co., 1922.

researchRecord.name: 1804-1920, 1.05 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: Photocopies of originals from the Putnam Family Papers. Includes 38 letters from Joseph Duncan, 8 letters from his brother Thomas, 4 letters from Matthew and 7 from James Findley. Diary kept while serving in Congress, 1829-1830. Business papers re: his father's estate, court cases in Jackson County and bill of sale for a slave. Numerous letters written by Elizabeth and her diaries, 1824-1846. Biographical sketches of Joseph and Elizabeth written by their daughter Julia Kirby. Pages from the journal of James Duncan, ca. 1829 and Julia Duncan, ca. 1852. Letters from Judge William Thomas re: the School for the Deaf in Jacksonville.

researchRecord.name: 1829-1840, 1 reel.
researchRecord.description: Land ownership record (1829-1840) and ledger (1830-1840) of Joseph Duncan.

researchRecord.name: 1832-1845, 42 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Joseph Duncan document school land sales and commissions signed by Joseph Duncan as Illinois governor; documents, promissory notes, deeds and will related to Duncan's estate.

researchRecord.name: 1833, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Joseph Duncan to H. H. Dearborn written on August 20, 1833. In the letter, Joseph Duncan describes advantages of early Illinois for a prospective settler.

researchRecord.name: 1835, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A commission of Charles R. Matheny as justice of the peace, Sangamon County, Illinois, signed by Governor Joseph Duncan on August 12, 1835..

researchRecord.name: 1835-1836, 4 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain 3 documents signed by Governor Duncan: 2 concern the sale of school lands, and a commission of Thomas C. Wilson as Tazewell County, Illinois, surveyor; and letter to Samuel Marsh, New York City, on a document, both concerning the sale of land in Oquawka, Illinois.

researchRecord.name: 1836, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A commission of Milo Bennett signed by Governor Duncan on May 8, 1836 as justice of the peace, Greene County, Illinois.

researchRecord.name: 1838, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A Commission of Sullivan Howard as justice of the peace, Henry County, Illinois, signed by Governor Joseph Duncan on January 11, 1838.

researchRecord.name: 1838 and 1841, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Joseph Duncan to Alexander P. Field written in 1838 concerns collection of election returns. Another letter written by Joseph Duncan to President John Tyler in 1841 concerns proposing constitutional amendment to limit the power of the presidency.

researchRecord.name: 1838 and 1852, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: Document, 1838, concerns title to land in the Military Tract, purchased by Joseph Duncan; and deed, 1852, for land in Warsaw, Illinois, owned by the Warsaw Land Company, of which Joseph Duncan had been president.

researchRecord.name: 1839, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A promissory note from June 25, 1839, from Joseph Duncan for payment of land purchased from Darius Ingalls.

researchRecord.name: 1839 and 1842, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: One letter from Joseph Duncan to George T.M. Davis written on March 5, 1839, concerns contracting out legal work. Another letter from Joseph Duncan to George T.M. Davis written on June 14, 1842, concerns Duncan's 1842 bid for Illinois governorship, his stand on relations with the Mormons and accomplishments in office.

researchRecord.name: In the Hardin Family Papers, 1733-1943, 9 linear feet.
